quiz.title: Context in JavaScript Quiz
quiz.description:
It's time to check your knowledge! Use this quiz to create a custom study guide. Note any answers that were marked incorrect, so you can study the relevant material and try this quiz again.

If you don't know the answer to a question, please do not guess. Instead, select "I don't know". It's OK not to know everything and to admit when we're unsure.

questions.question_text: Say we have a sendUpdate function that we want to use to send an account update to one of our customers (customer1). sendUpdate takes two arguments: the message text and the date. Which of the following shows the correct invocation of apply?

answers.html: sendUpdate.apply(customer1, [message, date]);
answers.comments: Correct! We call the apply method on the sendUpdate function, passing in two arguments: the desired context object, and an array containing the arguments to be passed along to sendUpdate.
answers.comments_html: Correct! We call the apply method on the sendUpdate function, passing in two arguments: the desired context object, and an array containing the arguments to be passed along to sendUpdate.

answers.html: sendUpdate.apply(customer1, { message, date });
answers.comments: Close! However, the arguments that will be passed along to sendUpdate should be enclosed in an array rather than in curly brackets.
answers.comments_html:
Close! However, the arguments that will be passed along to sendUpdate should be
enclosed in an array rather than in curly brackets.

answers.html: sendUpdate.apply(customer1, message, date);
answers.comments: Close! However, the arguments that will be passed along to sendUpdate should be enclosed in an array. This syntax would work if you used the call method method instead.
answers.comments_html: Close! However, the arguments that will be passed along to sendUpdate should be enclosed in an array. This syntax would work if you used the call method method instead.

answers.comments: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

questions.question_text:
The ____ method returns a copy of the function it is called on, in which the context is "set" to the object that's passed to it as an argument.

Example:

const thor = {
  firstName: "Thor",
  familyName: "Odinsson",
};
function introWithContext(line) {
  return `${this.firstName} ${this.familyName} says: ${line}`;
}

const thorIntro = introWithContext.______(thor);
thorIntro("Sup?");
// => Thor Odinsson says: Sup?
questions.incorrect_comments: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

questions.question_text: What argument/arguments do you need to pass to the call method? (select all that apply)

answers.comments: Correct! The call method allows you to override the default context for the function being called by passing a context object to it as the first argument.
answers.comments_html: Correct! The call method allows you to override the default context for the function being called by passing a context object to it as the first argument.

answers.text: A list of arguments to the function being called.
answers.comments: Correct! If the function being called takes any arguments, you pass those as additional arguments to call.
answers.comments_html: Correct! If the function being called takes any arguments, you pass those as additional arguments to call.

answers.comments: At a minimum, you need to pass a context object to call. If the function being called takes any arguments, you also need to pass those to call.
answers.comments_html: At a minimum, you need to pass a context object to call. If the function being called takes any arguments, you also need to pass those to call.

answers.comments: call is a method that is called on the function you want to execute: functionName.call(args)
answers.comments_html: call is a method that is called on the function you want to execute: functionName.call(args)

answers.comments: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

questions.question_text:
How can I use the call method to return person1's full name?

const person = {
  fullName: function () {
    return this.firstName + " " + this.lastName;
  },
};

const person1 = {
  firstName: "Sonia",
  lastName: "Sotomayor",
};

const person2 = {
  firstName: "Elena",
  lastName: "Kagan",
};

answers.html: person.fullName.call(person1);
answers.comments: Correct! The function being called is person.fullName, and we pass the desired context object (person1) as the argument. Since the fullName function doesn't take any arguments, we only need to pass the one argument to call.
answers.comments_html: Correct! The function being called is person.fullName, and we pass the desired context object (person1) as the argument. Since the fullName function doesn't take any arguments, we only need to pass the one argument to call.

answers.html: person1.call(fullName);
answers.comments: call is a method that needs to be called on a function, in this case person.fullName. The argument we pass to it is the context object, person1. The method call, therefore, should look like this: person.fullName.call(person1).
answers.comments_html: call is a method that needs to be called on a function, in this case person.fullName. The argument we pass to it is the context object, person1. The method call, therefore, should look like this: person.fullName.call(person1).

answers.html: person.call(person1);
answers.comments: Close! But call is a method that needs to be called on a function, and person is not a function! Instead we need to call the call method on person.fullName. The method call, therefore, should look like this: person.fullName.call(person1).
answers.comments_html: Close! But call is a method that needs to be called on a function, and person is not a function! Instead we need to call the call method on person.fullName. The method call, therefore, should look like this: person.fullName.call(person1).

answers.comments: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

questions.question_text: When a JavaScript function is invoked, which of the following are included in its execution context?

answers.text: The function's execution context includes all of these.
answers.html: The function's execution context includes all of these.
answers.comments: Correct! The function will have a function execution context that contains references to any functions or variables defined within it, but its overall execution context also includes the _global execution context_and the contexts of any functions it is enclosed in.
answers.comments_html: Correct! The function will have a function execution context that contains references to any functions or variables defined within it, but its overall execution context also includes the _global execution context_and the contexts of any functions it is enclosed in.

answers.comments: This is partially correct - the function's execution context does include the global execution context, but it also includes its own function execution context and the contexts of any functions it is enclosed in.
answers.comments_html: This is partially correct - the function's execution context does include the global execution context, but it also includes its own function execution context and the contexts of any functions it is enclosed in.

answers.comments: This is partially correct - the function does have its own function execution context, but its overall execution context also includes the global execution context and the contexts of any functions it is enclosed in.
answers.comments_html:
This is partially correct - the function does have its own function execution
context, but its overall execution context also includes the global execution
context and the contexts of any functions it is enclosed in.

answers.text: The context of anything available via the scope chain.
answers.comments: This is partially correct - the function's execution context does include the contexts of any functions it is enclosed in, but it also includes its own function execution context and the global execution context.
answers.comments_html: This is partially correct - the function's execution context does include the contexts of any functions it is enclosed in, but it also includes its own function execution context and the global execution context.

answers.comments: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

questions.question_text:
Given the following JavaScript code:

function hello() {
  console.log(this);
}
hello();

this will be the global object when the hello function is invoked.
questions.incorrect_comments: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

questions.question_text:
Inside a function, we use the ____ keyword to access the function's context object and its properties. For example, what keyword would you need to use in order to log byronPoodle's name when the warn method is called?

const byronPoodle = {
  name: "Byron",
  ageInYears: 2,
  warn: function () {
    console.log(_______.name);
    console.log(`Bark bark bark`);
  },
};
byronPoodle.warn();
questions.incorrect_comments: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.
questions.neutral_comments: Source/s:Introduction to ContextContext and Implicit Setting

questions.question_text: A function defined using _______ syntax does not create its own context.
